clauses.question: 1. What process should the Government use to set a new emissions reduction target in legislation?
clauses.answer: The Government sets a 2050 target in legislation now
clauses.notes:
We need to be clear that the goal is to reach net zero emissions by 2050. If appropriate, the experts at the independent Climate
 Change Commission could advise the government of the day to revise the target if new information becomes available.

clauses.question: 2. If the Government sets a 2050 target now, which is the best target for New Zealand?
clauses.answer: Net Zero Long-Lived Gases and Stabilised Short-Lived Gases - Long-lived gases to net zero by 2050 while also stabilising short-lived gases
clauses.notes:
This is a tricky question, with many different views. My understanding is that it certainly makes sense from a scientific perspective to
 treat methane different from other emissions. However this doesn't mean we shouldn't also be trying to immediately cut methane

 emissions. I would say we need to immediately cut the amount of methane in parallel with carbon dioxide, but the end stabilised
 target doesn't necessarily need to be net zero.

clauses.question: 3. How should New Zealand meet its targets?
clauses.answer: Domestic emissions reductions only (including from new forest planting)
clauses.notes:
I'm not convinced that we can rely on overseas reductions. We should close our ETS to international trade. Our priority should be to
 get New Zealand to net zero emissions. the

clauses.question: 4. Should the Zero Carbon Bill allow the 2050 target to be revised if circumstances change?
clauses.notes:
If circumstances change and the experts at the Climate Change Commission agree, then of course. The tricky thing will be to make

 this immune from political interference.

clauses.question: 5. The Government proposes that three emissions budgets of five years each (i.e. covering the next 15 years) be in place at any given time. Do you agree with this proposal?
clauses.notes: Giving certainly to businesses seems like a good idea, so they can tailor their investments accordingly.

clauses.question: 6. Should the Government be able to alter the last emissions budget (i.e. furthest into the future)?
clauses.answer: Yes - the third emissions budget should be able to be changed but only when the subsequent budget is set
clauses.notes:
We don't want our mitigation strategy to open to political interference. Only when recommended by the experts should budgets be

 changed.

clauses.question: 7. Should the Government have the ability to review and adjust the second emissions budget within a specific range under exceptional circumstances? See p36 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes: Again, only on the advice of the Climate Commission.

clauses.question: 8. Do you agree with the considerations we propose that the Government and the Climate Change Commission take into account when advising on and setting budgets? See p44 Our Climate Your Say
9. Should the Zero Carbon Bill require Governments to set out plans within a certain timeframe to achieve the emissions budgets?
clauses.notes:
Mostly meeting emissions budgets should be up to the market and the ETS. But governments can obviously help provide further
incentives and protect against market failures.

clauses.question: 10. What are the most important issues for the Government to consider in setting plans to meet budgets? For example, who do we need to work with, what else needs to be considered?
clauses.notes:
Infrastructure investment is one big area where the Government clearly needs to play a role. There's no point in investing in roads if a
high carbon price makes them uneconomical to use in the future.

clauses.question: 11. The Government has proposed that the Climate Change Commission advises on and monitors New Zealand's progress towards its goals. Do you agree with these functions? See p42 Our Climate Your Say
12. What role do you think the Climate Change Commission should have in relation to the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS)?
clauses.answer: Makes decisions itself in respect of the number of units available in the NZ ETS
clauses.notes: It's important that the settings of carbon budgets is not open to political interference.

clauses.question: 13. The Government has proposed that Climate Change Commissioners need to have a range of essential and desirable expertise. Do you agree with the proposed expertise? See p45 Our Climate Your Say
14. Do you think the Zero Carbon Bill should cover adapting to climate change?
15. The Government has proposed a number of new functions to help us adapt to climate change. Do you agree with the proposed functions? See p47 Our Climate Your Say
16. Should we explore setting up a targeted adaptation reporting power that could see some organisations share information on their exposure to climate change risks?
